title: What is the difference between a common name and a scientific name of species? - Quora

response.answer_text: For most species there is one preferred scientific name assigned in Latin with a Genus and species name presented in italics like, Homo sapiens. This name is assigned and undergoes carefully monitored changes if its membership in the Genus is reconsidered or there is a precedence of earlier naming for the species name. On the other hand a single species may have many common names assigned locally by local cultures and used in common parlance. For example from my expertise with cockroaches in the first half of my career as a biologist, Blattella germanica, in the USA is known as ‘The German Cockroach’ for apparently obvious reasons. But in New York it was known as the ‘Croton Bug’ because it seemed to appear in NYC at the time the Croton Aqueduct was built, which took much land by eminent domain that made it very unpopular. In Germany it is often called the ‘Russische Schabe’. In Russia it is called the ‘Polish Roach’ (in Russian). So, common names are ascribed often in erroneous and non methodical ways. In reality, B. germanica, likely became domesticated from a wild species, likely Blattella asahinai, that lives natively in Japan and not from a German origin. In domestication it became flightless, a good strategy for a pest to avoid being noticed. It was probably transported to Europe and Germany by trading caravans in the age of Marco Polo in the 1300’s or the early Portuguese ship trade in the 1500’s prior to it being given its Latin name, Blattella germanica, by Carolus Linnaeus who is considered the 'Father of Taxonomy' in the 1700’s. Interestingly, Blattella asahinai has been introduced as an invasive species to Florida USA and does actually fly while B. germanica does not fly. The two are ‘sibling species’ i.e. considered very recently diverged in evolutionary time. They have hybridized in Florida and their offspring are fertile and fly to patio lights! Yikes!! What should we call them? … something derogatory for sure! The ‘insect types’ of us cockroach scientists say “Watch for the research funding on these hybrids to surge when the flying Asia/German Cockroaches hit Washington DC!”

Jaguar - in Mexican Spanish this is called el tigre.  Tiger -in Spanish this is called el tigre Confusing? To avoid this confusion they are given a scientific name, usually binomial showing the fact they are big cats (Genus Panthera) and then a specific name (Species tigris = tiger , Species onca = jaguar) So Tiger = Panthera tigris and Jaguar = Panthera onca Works well to avoid any misconceptions regarding what is being spoken about.
